sentence: Significant buyback programs from large cap firms like Apple (AAPL), Home Depot (HD) and Boeing (BA) in the last 12 months have put stock buybacks in the spotlight.
There have also been some ETFs launched recently that provide targeted access to buyback strategies.
Here are some important takeaways related to buybacks and the ETFs that provide access to this strategy.

In the last 15 years, aggregate buybacks have exceeded dividends for large US firms

Focusing on dividend paying stocks is a well-known investment strategy, and one widely followed by investors focused on yield.
However, investors sometimes pay too little attention to buybacks, which is another way companies can return cash to shareholders (or at least to those who tender their shares back to the company).

It is interesting to note that in the last 15 years, S&P 1500 firms (which span the large- to small-cap equity spectrum) have returned more money to shareholders in aggregate through buybacks than ordinary dividends.
That pace has picked up recently in this mature bull market.

In February 2015, announced corporate stock repurchases jumped to a record $104.3 billion, more than the previous high of $99.8 billion announced in July 2006 (Data source: Trim Tabs Investment Research).
Though buybacks tend to get more attention during bull markets, the data indicates that an increase in buybacks is part of a longer-term trend.
As we can see in the chart below, companies in the S&P 1500 have been distributing more through buybacks than dividends since 1997 (Data source: S&P Dow Jones Indices).

Source: S&P DOW JONES INDICES Research: Examining Share Repurchasing and S&P Buyback Indices for the U.S. Market, January 2015

2.

Buybacks tend to be more volatile than dividends

While buybacks have exceeded dividends in aggregate, they do tend to be more volatile than dividends, as we saw during the 2008 downturn.
Buybacks are often viewed as a residual, undertaken when firms have excess cash after allocating towards their capital investments and dividend payments.
By contrast, firms tend to be averse to cutting dividends, as predictable dividends have come to be viewed as a proxy for stability in the cash flows of the underlying business.
Buybacks may also be motivated by extraneous factors such as executive compensation or to defend against potential takeovers, adding to their relatively unpredictable nature.

There are currently 104 ETFs listed in the US that provide targeted access to dividend strategies - that is, either the stock selection criteria or weighting methodology is based on dividend payments or dividend yield.
This count excludes ETFs that provide specific access to preferred stock or closed end funds.
A complete list of US listed ETFs is available here.
By contrast, there are currently 6 ETFs that provide targeted exposure to buyback strategies (or total shareholder yield that includes buybacks).
As of Mar 16, 2015, these 6 ETFs had an aggregate of $3.49 billion in assets and expense ratios ranging from 0.35% to 0.99%.
Only 3 ETFs (PKW, IPKW and SPYB) out of the 6 focus exclusively on buybacks, while the others use a combination of dividend, buyback and debt reduction metrics to screen and weight stocks.
This table provides a detailed comparison of these 6 buyback ETFs, including their expense ratios and methodologies for selecting & weighting stocks.
Through March 16 2015, buyback strategy ETFs had outperformed the broad market and their dividend counterparts over the trailing 12 months.

PowerShares Dividend Achievers Portfolio (PFM) returned 9.68% while its buyback counterpart PowerShares Buyback Achievers Portfolio (PKW) returned 15.55% in the trailing 12 months through March 16, 2015.
In fact, PKW has outperformed PFM and the S&P 500 in Year-To-Date, 1 year, 2 year, 3 year and 5 year returns as well (as of 03/16/2015).
PKW and PFM do not have a significant overlap in their holdings, further substantiating that buyback and dividend strategy ETFs provide exposure to different market segments.

Consumer Oriented Sectors Account for a larger weight than the technology sector

Due to the high profile buyback programs of Apple and IBM (IBM), share buybacks are often associated with the technology sector.
However, the consumer discretionary and consumer staples sectors account for a larger share of assets in PKW and IPKW than the technology sector.
Monitoring the sector exposure of these ETFs is important for investors looking to invest in these ETFs.

Sector breakup are as of 03/16/2015; * Sector breakup as of 03/12/2015; ** Sector breakup as of 12/31/2014; *** Sector breakup as of 02/28/2015

There are now more ETFs that offer targeted access to buyback strategies.
Though yield oriented investors have typically focused on dividend paying stocks, in the last 15 years aggregate buybacks have exceeded dividends for large US firms.
However, buybacks do tend to be more volatile than dividends, since they are often viewed as a residual capital expenditure.
Recently buyback ETFs like PKW have outperformed their traditional dividend oriented counterparts.
Finally, though buybacks are often associated with the technology sector, the consumer discretionary and consumer staples sectors account for a larger share of assets in buyback ETFs.
This article was co-authored by Aniket Ullal and Jania Kesarwani.
